biography.value:
"... I still have the damnable sting blisters from their catapults. WASPS! WHAT CREATURE PUTS WASPS IN BAGS AND THROWS THEM AT YOU?! Next Kobold I see I'm turning to pasteâ€¦"
- Guard Captain Nathaniel Greenbow, interviewed for this bestiary.

Kobolds are conniving, cowardly humanoids of a reptilian appearance who infest the dungeons, catacombs, and caverns of our world. Appearing as tiny dragonoids with scaled flesh and crocodile-like snouts, Kobolds are perhaps more clever than their outward appearance would lead one to believe. Within their tiny heads (as the creatures stand no more than two and a half feet tall) lies a brain churning with myriad ideas, though many include idiotically dangerous schemes. It is not uncommon for many Kobolds to perish before their first complete decade of life.

Mob Mentality. Kobolds, much like rodents, breed at an astonishingly quick rate as compared to other &reference[humanoid] species. Egg-layers like their draconic kin, Kobolds mature rapidly upon emerging from their shells, and assume their place within the ranks of their chittering society. Even upon reaching maturity, however, the Kobold is still a weak creature causing the colonies to stick together when exploring or hunting. Though Kobolds may defeat larger foes with sheer numbers, it is often at the cost of massive casualties on the Kobold's side. This, of course, hardly deters the resentful Kobolds, who have more eggs incubating away with the next infantry reinforcements just moments away from joining the fold.

Launch the Centipult. Stupid yet clever, Kobolds truly excel at two things: burrow-making and creating traps for unwary adventurers. Traps, of course, are the Kobold's speciality and they take relish in littering their lairs with copious defenses hewn from the natural resources of their home. Perhaps crushing logs were torn from the rafter struts of an abandoned temple, or carnivorous insects were placed into dropping ceramic pots to smash down upon foolish intruders. Never underestimate the ability of a Kobold to find some unsuspected way to impede your progress.

Trade Offs. Though strong in numbers, Kobolds may be defeated in several ways. Firstly, the creatures are born and mature within near total darkness, thus the sun weakens them and blinds their sensitive eyes. Kobolds are also nigh defenseless without the aid of their allies at their backs; often a lone Kobold with attempt to scurry away should they be caught out without their pack. Greedy and determined when it comes to self-preservation, Kobolds may be easily manipulated with smooth talk or a shiny trinket to line their pockets. Draconic in nature as well, the scuttling dragonoids can be used as crude translators of the &reference[dragon]'s tongue should you require such services on your journey.

  • Token artwork by Forgotten Adventures.
  • Bestiary entry by Penelope (Vyrnali).

description.value: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on an attack roll against a target if at least one of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s allies is within 5 ft. of the target and the ally isn't incapacitated.
This crude armor consists of thick furs and pelts. It is commonly worn by barbarian tribes, evil humanoids, and other folk who lack access to the tools and materials needed to create better armor.

You exhale, pushing all the air in your lungs forward in the direction of your outstretched hand. Your breath becomes a strong gust that throws objects and creatures around.


Candles, torches, and similar unprotected flames in range of the wind are extinguished.


[[/save str]]{Strength Save}

  • Failure: Targets are pushed 15 feet away from you in a direction following the line.

  • Success: Nothing

  • Area Hazard: Any movement going towards you against the direction of the latest gust of wind counts as movement through &reference[difficultterrain].

  • Concentration: On each of your subsequent turns, you can use a bonus action to both change the direction of the wind and have the spell occur again.

Your magical power manifests in various dramatic, but ultimately harmless ways. Whether by invoking forgotten magic, or simply by saying a few emotional words, you can create supernatural effects.


Utility Spell


You create one of the following effects:

  • Your voice booms up to three times as loud as normal for 1 minute.
  • You cause flames to flicker, brighten, dim, or change color for 1 minute.
  • You cause harmless tremors in the ground for 1 minute.
  • You create a sound that originates from a point of your choice within range. If you want, this sound can be a message of up to 6 seconds in length in your own voice, but not someone else's voice.
  • You alter the appearance of your eyes for 1 minute.


With your GM's permission, you can do a similar, harmless illusory effect.

You place two lodestones on either side of a broken object, then hold the broken object or its pieces together as you chant your spell, slowly joining the object back together.


Utility Spell

  • This spell repairs a single break or tear in an object you touch, such as broken chain link, two halves of a broken key, a torn cloak, or a leaking wineskin. As long as the break or tear is no larger than 1 foot in any dimension, and you have all the pieces, you mend it, leaving no trace of the former damage.


This spell cannot restore hit points to a &reference[construct]{construct}, vehicle, or object, and can only repair physical damage (&reference[bludgeoning], &reference[piercing], or &reference[slashing] damage). If used to reattach a body part, the body part is non-functional, as if the nervous system or circulatory system failed to connect properly.


You could put a shredded piece of paper back together, but you couldn't restore a burned note.

You call upon the power of darkness to isolate your target as they lose both sight and hearing.


[[/save constitution]]{Constitution Save}

  • Failure: Target is &reference[blinded] and &reference[deafened]. If you want, you can cause only one of the conditions to take effect. Target rolls again at end of their turns, ending effect on success.

  • Success: No effect.


Upcasting: Target one additional creature for each spell level above 2nd.

Calling out a word of power, you invigorate your target's spirit and bolster their life energy.


Healing


This spell has no effect on &reference[construct].

  • Target gains hit points equal to [[/healing 1d6 + @attributes.spellmod]]{1d6 + your spellcasting ability modifier} .


*Upcasting: Increase healing by [[/healing 1d6]]{1d6} for each spell level above 1st.

You call upon the power of water, forming a fog cloud where you reach out your hand.


Utility Spell

  • You create a 20-foot-radius sphere of fog centered on a point within range. The sphere spreads around corners.

  • Area Hazard: The area is &reference[heavilyobscured]. It lasts for the duration or until a wind of moderate or greater speed (at least 10 miles per hour) disperses it. This spell also doesn't function underwater.


Upcasting: The radius of the spell increases by 20 ft. for each spell level above 1st level.

A dagger is a short blade balanced both for thrusting and throwing. Daggers, as opposed to common knives, were made for combat. Many improvised weapons use the statistics of a dagger.


Properties:


&Reference[Finesse], &reference[light weapon], &Reference[Thrown]

Wrapped around your hand, this sling can fling smooth stones called bullets at great speeds. It uses bullets as ammunition.


Properties:


&Reference[Ammunition]
